taskTitle: Promote Team Performance Through Application of Emotional Intelligence

quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: During a project kickoff meeting, you present the timeline to stakeholders. Midway through, you notice a key client leaning back in their chair with arms crossed, frowning. Their team members seem anxious. You realize they're upset but haven't voiced concerns yet. The meeting continues for another 15 minutes before it ends.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What should you have done in that moment?

options.A: Continued the presentation as planned‚Äîthey would have spoken up if it was critical
options.B: Stopped and asked what concerns them, adjusting your communication approach
options.C: Asked if they want to schedule a follow-up meeting later
options.D: Finished quickly and sent a recap email afterward

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Read emotions and adjust communication approach

insights.explanation: EQ isn't just about managing your own emotions‚Äîit's about reading others' nonverbal cues (body language, facial expressions, tone) and adapting your approach in the moment.
insights.pmbokSupport: PMBOK 7: Emotional intelligence allows project managers to read nonverbal cues and adjust communication to meet stakeholder needs

insights.explanation: By pausing to acknowledge their concern, you demonstrate both self-management (staying calm) and social awareness (empathy). This prevents misunderstandings and builds trust.
insights.pmbokSupport: The four pillars of EQ: self-awareness, self-management, social awareness, and social skills work together to guide thinking and behavior

trapSection.explanation: Ignoring emotional signals creates gaps between what you think you said and what stakeholders actually heard.

trapTable.violation: Ignoring nonverbal communication leaves problems unresolved
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Lack of social awareness; missing opportunity to build trust

trapTable.violation: Delays resolution and leaves them upset during the meeting
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Reactive instead of proactive EQ application

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Emotional intelligence is the foundation of team performance. SUMMIT helps you navigate the emotional landscape of projects:

rows.action: Know your own emotions, triggers, strengths, and weaknesses. Understand how your mood and behavior affect your team.
keyQuestions: What am I feeling right now?
How might my emotions affect others?

rows.action: Read nonverbal cues: facial expressions, body language, tone of voice. Develop empathy for stakeholder concerns.
keyQuestions: Why might they feel that way?
What do they need from me?
rows.examKeywords: Social awareness, Empathy, Nonverbal cues, Read emotions

rows.action: Self-regulation: Think before acting. Control disruptive feelings. Stay calm under pressure.
keyQuestions: Am I reacting emotionally or responding thoughtfully?
rows.examKeywords: Self-regulation, Self-management, Control impulses, Think before acting

rows.action: Use EQ to inspire the team. Show genuine interest in their success. Build rapport and psychological safety.
rows.examKeywords: Motivation, Inspire team, Build relationships, Psychological safety

rows.action: Use emotional awareness to guide decision-making and persuasion. Adjust your communication style to the audience.
keyQuestions: How should I tailor my message?
rows.examKeywords: Influence, Communication adaptation, Stakeholder engagement, Authenticity

rows.action: Build trust through consistent emotional intelligence. Use EQ to resolve conflicts and difficult conversations.
keyQuestions: How can I deescalate this situation?
rows.examKeywords: Trust-building, Conflict resolution, Difficult conversations, Deescalation

pmbokConnection.quote: Emotional intelligence is the ability to recognize our own emotions and those of others. This information is used to guide thinking and behavior.

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: **Your emotions affect your team.** Notice them. Manage them. Use them to build stronger connections and solve problems faster.
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: Emotional intelligence is 40% knowing yourself + 60% reading and responding to others.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Look for scenarios where stakeholders are upset, team morale is low, or communication breaks down ‚Üí EQ is often the answer. Adjust your approach, show empathy, stay calm.
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: Emotional Intelligence - Basis of all leadership forms

secondScenario.title: üéØ Apply SUMMIT
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your top developer suddenly starts submitting work late and seems withdrawn in meetings. Other team members are starting to notice and you sense tension building. You could dismiss it as 'not your problem' since they're still delivering, or you could investigate.
secondScenario.question: Using emotional intelligence, what's your best next move?

options.A: Address it in the next team standup to motivate them publicly
options.B: Schedule a private conversation to understand what's going on‚Äîshow genuine concern
options.C: Wait and see if it resolves itself
options.D: Document the late submissions for performance review

quotes.text: Emotional intelligence is the ability to know your own feelings and to understand how those feelings are affecting others. You need to recognize when you're being harsh, when you're upset, and adjust your approach. This skill will transform how you lead teams and resolve problems.
quotes.author: Andrew Ramdayal

quotes.text: Emotional intelligence is a basis of all forms of leadership. Self-awareness and self-management are required to remain calm and productive during difficult project circumstances. Social awareness and social skills allow for better bonds with project team members and stakeholders.
quotes.author: PMI

fieldInsights.title: EQ as a Superpower
fieldInsights.insight: The best project managers aren't the smartest‚Äîthey're the most emotionally intelligent. They notice when someone's struggling, they stay calm during chaos, they make people feel heard. This is learned, not innate. Build it intentionally.

fieldInsights.title: Exam Pattern: EQ + Communication
fieldInsights.insight: Exam questions often present scenarios where communication breaks down or stakeholders are upset. The answer usually involves using emotional intelligence: adjusting your communication style, showing empathy, staying calm, reading nonverbal cues.

story.title: Climbing to Peak Performance
story.narrative: You're leading a climbing expedition to the summit. Each climber has different emotional needs, fears, and motivations. Your success depends on reading and responding to their emotional state at every turn.

scenes.description: Before leading anyone else up the mountain, know yourself. Are you calm? Anxious? Impatient? Your emotional energy sets the tone. A nervous guide makes the team nervous. A confident guide makes them confident. Check in with yourself: 'What am I feeling? How might that affect my team?'

As you climb, notice each climber's face. One looks terrified at the steep section. Another is lagging behind‚Äîdiscouraged? Tired? One is overconfident and taking risks. Read these signals. Empathy means: 'I see your fear. That's normal. We can do this together.'

scenes.visual: üéØ MANAGE REACTIONS at the Difficult Passage
scenes.description: A climber slips. Your heart races. You could panic (spreading fear) or stay calm and respond with clear directions. That's self-regulation. When the terrain gets tough, your ability to think before acting keeps everyone safe. 'Breathe. Focus. Guide.'

scenes.visual: üí° MOTIVATE at the Energy Dip (3/4 up the mountain)
scenes.description: Everyone's exhausted. The summit still looks far. This is where motivation matters. You remind them why they started. You celebrate how far they've come. You genuinely believe they can reach the top. Your conviction spreads to them. That's emotional influence.

scenes.visual: üé≠ INFLUENCE WITH INTEGRITY near the Summit
scenes.description: Different climbers need different messages. The nervous one needs reassurance. The overconfident one needs caution. The exhausted one needs inspiration. You adapt your message, your tone, your approach‚Äîbut stay true to your values. You're authentic, not manipulative.

You reach the summit together. The team trusts you because you read them, responded to them, stayed calm, and believed in them. That trust now carries through the descent and into the next climb. Emotional intelligence builds unbreakable bonds.

story.moral: The guide who **S**ees themselves, **U**nderstands their climbers, **M**anages their own emotions, **M**otivates the team, **I**nfluences with authenticity, and builds **T**rust reaches the summit safely and inspires climbers to climb again.
